title: Imphal - a bustling city in northeast India home to different ancient tribes
text:
14, 2015 
Imphal is an emerging tourist destination in northeast India. It is the capital of Manipur state and home to a plethora of tourist attractions. It is a perfect destination for an offbeat vacation and ensures of a memorable holiday. For lodgings, there are multiple good hotels in Imphal that you can pick from. 
Imphal, a small heaven on Earth, is the capital of India's northeastern state of Manipur, signifying the "land of jewels". It is a beautiful city set on the centre of Manipur Valley and is the chief centre of governance, education, commerce, finance, and tourism. It is a melting pot of several cultures that were basically brought in by the people of numerous tribes who have been living in the hills and valleys of the region since several centuries. A majority of the total population of the city is formed by Meitei tribal people. Today, the rich history and the tradition of the tribes can only be deciphered from the local folklore, dance, music, oral traditions, etc. which are still very much in practice. The major tribes in the city are Meitei, Pangans, Bamons, Tangkhuls, Kabuis, and Paite. In addition to these, there also exists a sizeable population of Bengalis, Marwaris, Biharis, and Punjabis. 
The name "Imphal" is the distorted version of Yumphal that signifies "land of many villages". It is nestled in the best natural settings that include crisscrossing hills, valleys, and forests. Multiple rivers and their tributaries flow through it, making the land very fertile as well as enriching the wildlife. The natural beauty of the place is simply stunning and to add more to that the climate here is almost always temperate. At present, it is the largest and most developed city in the state housing several flourishing medium-scale industries, banks, educational institutions, hospital, restaurants, and hotels in Imphal . 
For the tourists, the place is a perfect destination for an offbeat holiday. It is home to numerous tourist attractions and allures that date from the medieval era till the present era. It was the seat of many medieval kingdoms, the significant ones being Khunjaoba, Pakhangba, Khagemba, and Maharaja Bhagyachandra, and there are numerous monumental structures including the temples and ceremonial places still dotting the place. Amongst the popular places that you just cannot miss while touring the city: Manipur Zoological Gardens, Shree Govindajee Temple, Kangla Fort, Samban-Lei-Sekpil Garden, Manipur State Museum, Ima Keithel, War Cemeteries, Sekta Archaeological Living Museum, War Cemetery, Jama Masjid, Khonghampat Orchidarium, and Keibul Lamjao National Park. 
The history buffs will enjoy visiting the War Cemetery, which was consecrated as a memorial and token of respect for the British and Indian Manipuri soldiers who sacrificed their lives during the Second World War. It is a quiet place and easily accessible. Each cemetery is beautifully kept and marked with bronze plaques. Additionally, the Kangla Fort is yet another prominent historical attraction of the city. It is the royal palace of the king of Manipur. It is grand and beautiful. Until 2003 Assam Rifles of Indian Army was in control of the fort and after 2003 the fort was opened for tourists. 
Simply visit the city during the next vacation. The best time to visit the city is from October to March.
